content.description: There is a bulging flake with a small tree growing in it to start.  After the flake it’s low angle slab to the top.
content.location: It’s to the right of picnic table number three.

content.description: This problem is the namesake for the area. If you're short jump or pad stack to gain the first two holds on the lip. Throw a high left foot rock over to a good left hand dish and figure out how to work your feet up.
content.location: Park in the second to last pullout headed toward the frontside and take the trail to where it Ts. Continue left and the boulder should be on your right with the high start holds visible from the trail.

content.description: Crux mounting the boulder, but it'll keep you on your toes all the way up. Great slab movement! The only thing keeping from being four stars is the awkward first couple moves.
content.location: Sherman: "6 feet right of picnic table platform #3 is a white wall with a line of brown huecos."

content.description:
**As of January 2010 this problem has been closed**

  Start sitting in the back of the cave on flake jugs.  Traverse left on jugs until a hard drop down move is encountered.  Stay tight and avoid the dab, and pull out of the cave,  Finish up the steep face with good holds above.  Careful if your pumped enough it's still possible to fall off here.
content.protection: pads, the thinner the better for inside the cave
content.location: Pass the picnic area and head up the short steep slab,  On your left is a small cave crawl back in here for the start.  Descent is easiest to walk down slabs back towards the road.

content.description:
Mostly moderates here with many V0 - V1 problems.  The harder problems here are Donkey Head V4 and the namesake Michael Kenyon V4.  The area is easy to get to and next to picnic areas so don't expect seclusion or quietness.   

  ATTENTION! Everything behind Table 3 is closed to climbing, including parts or all of Michael Kenyon, Mission Impossible and Donkey Head rocks.
